Alice's main goal for her novels is to fill a gap in children's fiction. She noticed that many books for teenagers focus on negative experiences or are complete fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books are different. Alice always taught English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel "Tale of Troy," and she loves seeing children go from being bored to interested. She sees her writing as a continuation of her teaching.

Alice was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also suggested she would enjoy a creative writing course. At first, Alice was surprised and didn't want to spend her summer on a course she thought unnecessary. But she had to send her best piece of fiction to be accepted. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby, and was accepted into the course. During the course, other students gave her great feedback and suggested she publish her story. With only school report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked for a year off to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, a critic and editor, helped her a lot with editing. Alice says they complement each other well; he helps improve her writing by suggesting changes, while she likes to add more scenes.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to compete in a special race. The race would be between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

"I'm looking forward to it," Jonny said at the start line. "I've never done anything like this before; it's exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it's very cold right now, so I'll be warm in the car." Alistair was also excited. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair was dressed in full winter cycling gear. He wasn't worried about the cold. "To be honest," he said, "I've seen his driving before, so I'm not sure he'll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, which is about 350 meters up. This might not be a problem for the car, but Alistair's first few miles included a steep 25 percent incline, making it tough for him from the start. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair sped off on his bike, heading up a hill and then across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny got into the car and was soon on the road. The next time they would see each other would be at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny's early confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first obstacle: a giant tractor came out of a field and onto the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he joked to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it's because of this farmer!" After dealing with the tractor, Jonny was back on track, driving into the morning mist.

Meanwhile, Alistair was struggling with the steep slope. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion kept moving, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun coming out, he had a chance to show his skills. He put his head down, feet on the pedals, and started picking up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have been around since before cars were invented, and the roads are not made for speed. Jonny carefully navigated a very narrow corner and drove through a stream on the road. Once past the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final straight to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping, he reached the line and stopped. 

Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he raised his arms in victory. "Yes!" he shouted. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car and got out. "Well done," Jonny said, feeling disappointed. "I'm gutted."

Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience because of the silence. When you bounce the ball on the soft grass, you hear only the sound of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful audience create a special atmosphere that feels separate from the outside world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to block out everything except the game and the point I'm playing. The silence is only broken by applause and cheers when a point is won. Even though there are 15,000 people watching in the stadium and millions more on TV, I am so focused that I hardly notice them. 

In 2008, I played against Roger Federer in the Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach forever, taught me that Wimbledon is the most important tournament. By age 14, I was already telling my friends that I would play and win there one day. Before 2008, I had played and lost twice to Federer in the finals. The 2006 loss wasn't too hard because I was just happy to have reached the final at age 20. But the 2007 loss was devastating because I knew I could have done better. It wasn't my skills that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that match. Losing is always painful, but it's worse when you know you had a chance to win. 

Toni, who is a very tough coach, usually doesn't comfort me, even when I win. But after that loss, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances to win Wimbledon. I told him he didn't understand, that it might have been my last chance. I know a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I felt I had missed a big one in 2007. 

However, Toni was right. I got another chance in 2008. I was confident I had learned from my previous defeat and that my mindset would be strong this time. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends, but we didn't talk about the match. They knew I was already mentally preparing for it, and I needed that space to be mine alone until the match started.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make Jane Goodall famous by creating articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventurous spirit or her role as a woman in a male-dominated field, which can overshadow her actual work.

Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading pioneer in her field and the world's top zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew they ate meat or used tools, and we didn't realize they had emotions and social systems similar to ours. We also didn't know that chimpanzee communities across Africa have different cultural traditions. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is the most important work in chimpanzee research. Her long-term study of wild apes in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world.

Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and because chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, there were signs of the person she would become. One clear example was in the autumn of 1939 when she was five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and the police, neighbors, and family searched for her. As it got dark, she suddenly reappeared with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked where she had been, and Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. She had hidden in a henhouse for five hours to find out. This curiosity can be seen as the start of her career as a biologist.

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist who can speak in many different voices. During our first conversation, she used the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV, cartoons, and health and safety training videos. She recently did a voiceover about back injuries and had to quickly learn how to say many medical terms.

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. Many actors think they can do funny voices, and some can, but there is more to it. You have to make the script come alive for an audience that can’t see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceover work, but they often don’t get the parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.

After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning to have a regular acting career. During the course, she sang jingles for TV ads. One day, the studio manager suggested she try out for a rabbit character in a cartoon. It seemed silly, but she tried it for fun and got a major part. Shirley realized she was good at voices and decided to pursue voiceover work. In her second film, she played the main character, her brother, and her mother.

Adult female actors often provide voices for young boys and girls because their voices are lighter. Hiring child actors involves complex procedures, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are her favorite part of a job that also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. She says those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but smiling while talking helps make your voice sound cheerful.

The competition for voiceover work is tough, and having a good showreel is important. A showreel is a recording that shows what an artist can do. Shirley says it’s worth investing in a strong showreel, and there are agencies that help voiceover artists create them. She believes her success is due to persistence as much as talent. Whether it’s making your showreel or practicing your voices, it’s about setting goals and not giving up.

For those interested in a voiceover career, Shirley recommends attending specialist workshops that cover all types of voiceover work. She also believes a love for human sound is essential. She describes herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she performs. After doing a particular voice in the studio, she might speak like that for hours or even days. Her children are used to their mom talking in different voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. 

In my case, I had a typical cartoonist’s childhood: I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as ‘the kid who draws.’ I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and in a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are basic, but it’s still a tough job. You shouldn’t try to become a cartoonist unless you feel you can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t refuse any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are mostly over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with average talent but good business skills often do better than artistic geniuses who lack those skills.

I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t even show their work to others! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster—it could actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. Normally, I hate throwing things away, but for some reason, I decided to get rid of it. I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes, even though I was starting to regret it. He asked if he could have it, and I agreed. We went our separate ways, but I felt sad about my decision for years.

Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. The email was from a man named Keith Rushton, who restores guitars. He told me, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it was probably outdated but used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell the guitar back to me. I was so emotional and would have paid anything, but his price was fair.

I had forgotten that my dad used to put name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have found this whole situation funny. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular then. I loved the calming sound of the classical guitar, but I didn't make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn't need to be a great musician to be a rock star.

When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the urge to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder, as electric guitars are meant to be played. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingertips felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone, so now that I'm learning it again, I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are others my age with similar experiences. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," which is about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one talking about how dangerous not getting enough sleep can be. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who struggle with sleep know how important it is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, missing the last hour or two of sleep. This is usually the REM stage, or 'Rapid Eye Movement,' which is when we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives to 90 will spend six or seven years dreaming. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research didn't fully support this idea. The study of dreams shifted to focus more on their physical origins rather than psychological ones. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that people who are interested in creativity use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't all people, like teachers, software designers, and politicians, need to think creatively? According to Stickgold, dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create new ideas that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ignore the obvious and make unexpected connections, which is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, or one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come so quickly that I can barely type fast enough. I don't know exactly how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, which has a beautiful view of the sea, you can see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading figure in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate famous paintings from artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so accurate that even art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the original paintings are worth millions, Susie's reproductions sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them.

Susie has many clients, including galleries and private collectors, but she doesn't usually reveal their names. Some collectors buy her copies to show off, like a celebrity who claims to own a Van Gogh when it's actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. Some people use her copies to save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying her copy at home.

Susie is honest about her work. She tries to make her reproductions look as real as possible and signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as an original is illegal, and although some people do it, Susie has never been tempted because it could ruin her reputation. She admits she isn't wealthy and has had tough times, but her situation is more stable now.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. This job taught her to be precise and careful, which helped her in her current work. She advises young artists to learn to draw accurately and study hard. Susie can create anything from plant drawings to perfect copies of old masterpieces, but she now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas.

Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie disagrees. She says impressionists painted quickly but were also very detailed, which is hard to achieve. Despite her skills, Susie doesn't create her own original art. She once tried painting fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. Susie is a perfectionist and is happy with her career as a copyist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest sailor. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a strong connection with the boats she sailed around the world, working in perfect harmony with them. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly longed to be back at sea, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop race around the world, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was a small, cramped space where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even down to the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial. She proudly displayed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her boat was her entire world, and she took great care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her realize how humans take what they want and move on. 

When I visited Ellen’s office, she had just finished a heated conference call. She explained why urgent action is needed to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways to not use them up," she said. Initially, her message was to use less, but she now focuses on re-using, like promoting reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, Ellen has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she admits, "but I love learning. The current situation is something I can't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters."

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to create a sustainable future. "I miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It defines who I am. At sea, you are connected to everything around you, focused on records, practicalities, and survival. My new message isn't as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I've done before."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to encourage them to try outdoor activities. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted that a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – there's still a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father's ambition? Paul says, 'This isn't about me wanting fame through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, why not now? We regularly check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record attempt. The more exciting the record, the more interest it gets. This creates a challenge for Jordan. People might say that focusing on records takes away from the enjoyment, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll end this project and go to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they aren't listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their music. The numbers are discouraging for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells just 300 copies. I find that surprising. So, why is interest in classical music declining, even though it's been around for centuries? Older people often blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who love classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big classical music fan. I like many music styles, but my classical music collection is probably around that 3% mark. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm, with many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk, play, and think fast. Experts say we can't focus for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop songs also have lyrics that are more interesting to us than long classical pieces without words. The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why more people like classical concerts as they get older, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some people blame schools for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play in their school orchestra. They practice early and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it's not their first choice when listening for fun. When we relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret that I’m here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be kicked out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best one here!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He seemed lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, which made Bonnie happy. She was so focused on putting a saddle on Maverick that she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m serious because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She got him to walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d be good at jumping.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. Cody is a 15-year-old Australian who has already released several successful songs. How did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." He remembers that he was also swimming and surfing every day, which were more important to him back then. At 13, while attending high school, he posted a few videos online. These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos on their social media. Cody, who had recorded more videos at home, was happy to share them. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer, training with top coaches and focusing on his sport. But then record labels showed interest, and he had a tough decision to make: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very difficult for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career," he says. "Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked reactions. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody says it’s important to have a close group of great people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has days of doubt. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight and travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support and encourage me." Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say "yes" to your big opportunity, even when it’s a bit scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I’d see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to stop the buildings from flooding when the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town's adults for long hours to show I could do it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. There was fragile ice on both sides, and solid ice downstream. As I changed out of my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn't know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip, which I read before bed. I patted the chain and went to the kitchen. "Morning, Rex," Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. "You're up early for a Saturday. I'll make brunch after your training. Be careful." "Thanks, Mom." I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa. "Watch where you're going," he shouted. "Where are you going?" "Sorry, Grandpa. I'm going kayaking." My wetsuit should have made that clear. He sees me kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore his temper, but it's getting harder. "Why train? You didn't win the competition," he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom gave me a sympathetic smile. "Don't mind him. He's..." "…not himself right now," I finished. I didn't say he's always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a kid, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic. Those photos are still on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don't go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies now, and maybe one day, my own photo in National Geographic. Still, part of me wants to stay loyal to him, even though he's grumpy. Mom smiled. "At least he's coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your dedication, even on cold days!" I smiled back as I peeled my banana. "It'll be warmer in South America," I said. "If I find sponsors for my expedition." She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse in the backyard.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unfinished painting by Grandpa. It was different from his usual work. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river, but not one she recognized. It might not even be a real river, just an imaginary one. The picture was strange and shapeless, but beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green, drawing the eye into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, too detached, showing her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? I mean, for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn't finished it yet, so maybe he's going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't resist. It's such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I suppose you can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone..." "Ignoramus, he said." "... every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he had to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I will cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm unlucky that way.

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's very cute, small, painted white with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, so I was excited when she gave it to me. But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my small room for a while. I don't mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest, and I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom... Then I thought, if I can't cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They 'borrow' things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be difficult to meet fans' expectations. People who love the book have strong opinions about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not the humans', which made filming more complicated. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' perspective. They wore out many pairs of jeans doing this! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was making the shadows look right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I especially remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right, which other directors struggled with. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it almost impossible for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and had to be sewn into the dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most scenes away from the Borrowers’ home were shot with actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren’t accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, people pretending to be friends, and the requests for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything’s going to be fine,” I reassure her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the band is here for recording, we’re staying permanently. I chose this school because I want to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, not very friendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. She seems confused but types “McGraw” on her keyboard. Luckily, not many people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she says, then hands me the schedule. English Literature is my first class. I like English, so that’s good. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night to avoid looking lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Perfect, no one will suspect anything! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oops, maybe not the best choice. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses. “Desert... McGraw?” she asks. “Here.” She smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we’ll read this year, she lets us socialize. All teachers should do this. “So why’d you move here?” my new friend asks. I have options. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. A little lie works for now. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” She doesn’t seem too interested. Perfect.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do a lot. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being a teenager in America is like now. Teenagers can't just go to school and be average; they need to stand out. Being average is not enough, and not having big goals is seen as being lazy. 

Teenager Kristen Loose explains that people, especially adults, often forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have lots of homework, tests, activities outside of school, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home. On top of all this, they try to have a social life. Even though these pressures are normal for teenagers now, negative stereotypes about them still exist. The media often portrays teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might fit this description, it's not fair to say all teenagers are like this.

Kristen Loose says that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She believes this is mostly wrong. She admits she keeps her phone close most of the time, but not just for fun. It's a tool that helps teenagers manage their busy lives. Today, students are expected to have instant access to information and be reachable at all times, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their work anywhere. They might listen to language lessons instead of music on the way to school. Schoolwork and activities now need attention all day, adding to teenagers' busy schedules.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teenagers get enough sleep. Also, 28% of teenagers said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are so tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen doesn't spend much of this time on social media or TV. She uses it to volunteer. She says people think teenagers only care about themselves, but she loves helping others. Her favorite part of the week is volunteering, where she makes a positive impact in her school and community.

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will still be proving it wrong and making progress. There will be a new generation of students making a big impact before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live near Bishop, a small town in the US surrounded by wilderness, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project with a twist: it's part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside was a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to track temperature changes. Two GPS trackers were on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had driven seven hours to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chanted, and the balloon started rising. Some of them ran and tracked it with powerful flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet, shared sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at the clear sky, hard to believe it was just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it’s almost the size of a house. Then it bursts in a dramatic explosion. A parachute helps the equipment inside the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day, using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who noted they’ve lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. Then they had to decide whether to drive or walk – it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘It’s important to remember that these students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What seems wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It was a bit disappointing, but it was also a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might work above mountain ridges. And it was another adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that she wasn't interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest started by accident. Her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a common phase for kids, which she hadn't gone through. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. It amazed her, and she realized she wanted to pursue it.

I asked Chloe about the support she received because Palaeontology wasn't a typical career choice for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. Chloe was nervous, worried he might find her annoying with her questions. However, he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I mentioned how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe thinks films like Jurassic Park have increased interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She feels that palaeontologists in movies are often shown as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks, which isn't accurate. Her job involves digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific journals. She also believes in communicating scientific findings to the public, especially young people, to clear up misunderstandings about science and inspire them.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, which aimed to show dinosaurs accurately. She advised the makers, ensuring the dinosaurs were the right size and from the same time period. The show attracted audiences of all ages because it portrayed dinosaurs more realistically than movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us there's still much to learn. Palaeontology, she says, is like a form of time travel.

I'm going to say this just once: when you're traveling by car with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" And really, once you arrive, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So, if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" I'm sure no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who hear that question over and over during long car trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs you haven't seen, listen to music, or do puzzles you've had for a while, while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, there's mom or dad, who gives out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio station, and adjusts the temperature—basically, they make sure everything goes smoothly and act like a concierge on the road! Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. What? He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot reach back to separate us as the car speeds up and swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a while. The beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Soon after, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the car isn't going fast, and the window isn't open. Where's it coming from? My brother is in the next seat, quietly blowing air on me. He's on his side, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. Just breathing? What's the problem with that? The anger builds. Tim gets yelled at, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again—for now. Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us kids in the back seat. For example, when we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yes. We're here. Get out of the car." "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." "Oh, well, then maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move as far away as they can from the kids who have annoyed them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope customers will love the experience and come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a space where people can connect without screens, as everyone is often busy with their phones and gadgets. The games in their café are called 'Eurogames', which have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. 

One popular co-operative Eurogame is Pandemic, created by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He remembers playing it with friends and feeling scared but excited, and everyone felt good at the end, win or lose. Leacock loved board games since childhood, even though he often felt disappointed by them. With his uncle's help, he started designing better games. Pandemic became very successful, and its sequel added more storytelling, similar to video games, where characters develop and the world changes.

Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Video games have made playing games more normal, as many people now play games on their smartphones. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says that video games and board games have learned a lot from each other. Many people who play video games are now open to playing board games too. 

In the past, video games allowed people to play together in the same room, but now many games are played online, where players are not physically together. This has led some people to look for games they can play with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun; it brings people together in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many setbacks. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced his music taste. He was 12 when he first heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between playing tennis at a national level and music, as he spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, "I was good at tennis, but it wasn't what I wanted to do forever. It was too much hard work." At 17, he left school to pursue a music career. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as passionate about a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to be a musician, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano daily. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't come. Jamie says, "In my artist career, I've often been in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, I've been in the right place." Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK, helping new artists start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that aiming for chart success is okay. He asks, "Don't you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He believes in writing songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well. Jamie is straightforward about wanting to write hit songs that reach number one. He isn't arrogant; he just knows he has a talent for it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on writing great music. "When I go into the studio, the goal is to write the best music of next year. It's not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs," he says.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. He is a 'street trials cyclist,' which means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. 

When I met him for an interview at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, many local boys recognized him. Even older people came to say he is a 'legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity, even though I was skeptical at first. Before each stunt, he explained what he planned to do, and I often doubted he could succeed. But he always did. When I praised him, he seemed uninterested and a bit sad. Despite his online fame, Tony doesn't enjoy being a celebrity. He finds it hard to socialize and prefers doing things rather than talking about them. 

This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. He admits that this technology helps him make a living. He sometimes feels that everyone is too focused on cameras and screens, but he doesn't complain. Thanks to his videos, he earns well from what would have been just a hobby in the past.

From my experience interviewing top athletes, I know that two things are important for success: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent and help athletes keep going despite failures. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on easy but new obstacles. He just got up and tried again until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he takes unnecessary risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport. They probably never rode a trials bike and don't know the technical details. He gets expert advice to minimize risks. Tony is careful about the dangers. He believes it's wise to be aware of them. Some people never feel scared, but Tony feels fear and overcomes it. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. Sometimes he rides around to get in the right mindset before a new stunt. He knows he must stay calm before jumping. If he fully commits, he is fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has completed many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge was walking on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert in high-wire walking. Even though she had some circus skills, she found high-wire walking very different. "The training was a shock," said Helen. "I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she said afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, using a kite, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He was stuck in a hostel bed for ten days without medicine because he had no money for hospital bills or to go home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night, because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat. The work is tough. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some areas and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but often it is wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a lab, where we will look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues to keep them happy! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm in our food lab, and other times I'm traveling abroad to buy raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety and lack of routine in my job, although the chocolate itself is still my favorite part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things such as balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see how their children are doing. 

Sophia explains that for a circus career, performers need to avoid repeating the same acts – it's important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always work on improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work a few months each year. But the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only travel with the circus while you're young, and then you need to think about other career options.

The course also teaches business planning. Many former students have started businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns that it's not a job for making a lot of money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive – but a lot of fun!"

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the main singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers, but that's not true. They often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

"What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!"

"Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There's often no sheet music to look at. I'll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous stores and are popular with celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered many business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. Not everyone agreed with her choice, but she was sure it would work. She worked with her mother, who had a natural talent for business, even though she had never had a career. The design of the satchels was inspired by children's storybooks. 

Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs at first, but they became important for her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To gain attention, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew. Her company now produces satchels much faster. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity will be seen with a satchel next. Instead of spending money on online ads, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting.

There was a difficult time when another company copied her satchel design. Because of this, she now ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. People who visit her offices notice the positive atmosphere, and employees enjoy working there. There is a new factory, but Julie believes it's the team that makes the place special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with her schoolwork. 

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The cycling track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, "I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all. When the excitement is gone, there's no point. Luckily, I found a new career."

Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. "We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport," she says. "The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a larger group."

The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, "Some people doubt if celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it to promote themselves, which might hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should."

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to become more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course taught by a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher didn't listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about her frustration. She posted it online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to ask her to join Isotope. At first, she was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. But Joss convinced her this wouldn't happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was an amazing night. Ana says she prefers writing songs about difficult times because she has more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how unhappy it made him. While she hopes fans will like her songs, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an amazing trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea.
